Context:
Program Name: Community Worker
Code: C101
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $3,723.00
International Tuition: $17,435.00
Location: St. James Campus
Program Availability:
- Fall 2023: Closed for domestic and international students
- Winter 2024: Not Available for domestic students, Not Available for international students
- Spring 2024: Not Available for both domestic and international students
Centre: Community Services & Early Childhood
School: Social & Community Services
Experiential Learning: Field Placement
Program Description: Prepares students to work for progressive social change with organizations, communities and individuals across a range of issues such as poverty, housing, legal rights, discrimination, food justice, immigration and refugee settlement. Approved education program by the Ontario government.

Context:
The text discusses an approved education program for Community Workers offered by a college with strong ties to over 350 agencies across the Greater Toronto Area (GTA). graduates of this program may apply to receive the additional designation of RSSW (Registered Social Service Worker), and there are extra fees for this designation.

The Community Worker Program features include a long-standing relationship with Anishnawbe Health Toronto (AHT), where graduates of AHTâ€™s Community Health Worker Training Program can gain direct entry into the second year of the Community Worker program. The annual Tommy Douglas Institute is also mentioned, which brings participants together to explore community, education and social justice in the twenty-first century.

The role of a Community Worker includes working with individuals and communities at all levels towards positive social change, and being committed to inclusion, equality, diversity, and human dignity. The program teaches a variety of important skills, such as anti-oppressive and intercultural practice, critical analysis, group facilitation, community organizing, advocacy, and policy analysis.

The Community Worker Program structure includes classroom instruction and two supervised field placements, with theory, analysis, and practice presented through popular education and learner-centered approaches. The program is divided into four core areas: community work theory and practice, social and political analysis, group skills and counselling, and field placement and seminar.

The faculty are experienced educators who come from backgrounds in local, national, and global activism. No specific factual information such as names, emails, or numbers were mentioned in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Community Worker Program C101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text is about a Community Worker program offered by a college. The program has strong ties to community partners and advocacy organizations, providing students with opportunities for field placements in areas such as poverty, settlement services, housing, food justice, education, HIV/AIDS, Indigenous services, arts-based agencies, and anti-violence. Students will develop relationships with community partners and have the opportunity to gain practical skills and professional experience.

Students come from diverse backgrounds, including mature students and high school graduates, as well as those seeking a career change. Those passionate about human rights and social justice, committed to working with diverse communities, and bringing a mature and professional approach are encouraged to apply.

Field placements occur in semesters 2, 3, and 4. Students must complete a Police Vulnerable Sector Check before commencing their field placement due to the requirements of the community partners. The fees for these checks vary by region and are the responsibility of the student.

The program offers an Accelerated option for those with a diploma or degree, making them eligible. Program option courses are often taught by practitioners currently working in the field. Types of Community Worker Field Placements mentioned include poverty, settlement services, housing, food justice, education, HIV/AIDS, Indigenous services, arts-based agencies, and anti-violence.

No specific factual information like years or names is provided within the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Community Worker Program C101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
This text provides information about the Community Worker program offered by the college and the career opportunities and educational pathways for graduates. The following facts can be extracted from the text:

* The Community Worker program is an approved education program by the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers (OCSWSSW).
* Graduates of this program may apply to receive the additional designation of RSSW (Registered Social Service Worker), with extra fees applying.
* Career options for Community Worker graduates include: shelter supervisors, international development workers, immigration and refugee settlement, community development, health and community advocacy in food justice, Indigenous rights, and climate justice.
* Graduates may apply for advanced entry into other programs such as: Community Development B.A. at Algoma University, Community Development B.A. at Humber College, Policing & Community Well-Being (B.A) at Trent University, Professional Communications B.A. and Justice Studies B.A. at Royal Roads University, Social Work B.A. programs at Toronto Metropolitan University, and York University.
* Required courses for the first semester include: CWRK 1001 - Introduction to Community Work, CWRK 1005 - Human Rights in Community Work Practice, and CWRK 1008 - Interpersonal Communication. Additionally, CWRK 1020 is mentioned but not included in the list of required courses.
* Students are encouraged to work with the field education coordinator to identify placement opportunities that do not require the vulnerable sector check. They may also apply for Suppression and Destruction of Record or Record Suspension at their specific regional police services.
* For more information, students can visit the Clinical Pre-placement website.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Community Worker Program C101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
SEMESTER 1:
- CWRK 1008: Interpersonal Communication
- CWRK 1020: Sociology: Understanding Power and Anti-Oppression
- ISHU 1035: Indigenous Studies
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (General Education Elective)
- CWRK 1048: Climate Justice
- CWRK 1050: Fieldwork Seminar I
- CWRK 1051: Fieldwork I
- CWRK 2014: Community and Campaign Organizing
- CWRK 1030: Canadian Politics: A Critical Approach (General Education Elective)

SEMESTER 2:
- CWRK 1008 or COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication): depending on placement test results
- CWRK 2019: Canadian Social Policy
- CWRK 2039: Fieldwork Seminar II
- CWRK 2038: Fieldwork II
- Program Specialization Course: CWRK 2026 (Housing & Homelessness) or other program specializations (Urban Aboriginal Issues, Restorative Justice, International Development, Community Legal Issues, Housing and Homelessness, Food Justice)

SEMESTER 3:
- COUN 2003: Counselling
- CWRK 2043: Community Development: Programs and Funding
- CWRK 2019 or other program specialization course
- CWRK 2035: Immigration and Settlement: Working with Immigrant and Refugee Populations

SEMESTER 4:
- Program Specialization Course: CWRK 2033 (Food Justice) or other program specializations (Urban Aboriginal Issues, Restorative Justice, International Development, Community Legal Issues, Housing and Homelessness)
- CWRK 2032: Global Politics
- CWRK 2039: Fieldwork Seminar II
- CWRK 2038: Fieldwork II
- CWRK 2044: Critical Digital Community Work
- CWRK 2016: Group Facilitation

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Establish constructive relationships with individuals concerned with community work.
- Describe their personal values and motivation as a community worker.
- Serve in a variety of grassroots community organizations especially in the areas of co-operatives, seniors and community legal services.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Community Worker Program C101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Information:
- The program focuses on grassroots community organizations, specifically in the areas of cooperatives, seniors, and community legal services.
- Students will be comfortable in community work roles ranging from direct service to classical advocacy and organizing.
- Students will understand and articulate the special needs of multicultural groups.
- Students will analyze social inequalities and demonstrate creativity in the organization of new services and institutions to meet community needs.
- Students will work with groups to identify their own needs.
- Students will access existing services and community resources.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition for programs starting in Fall 2022: $3,723.00
- International Tuition for programs starting in Fall 2023: $17,435.00
- Additional costs are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.

Financial Assistance:
- The program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
- Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent.
- Grade 12 English (C or U) is required.
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English, OR may consider upgrading to achieve the credit(s) needed in English.
- Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to the program. Applicants may be required to have grades higher than the minimum stated.

Course Exemptions:
- College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide page.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Community Worker Program C101 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information on international and domestic student applications, special requirements for field placements, and contacts for the School of Social & Community Services at George Brown College.

For international students:
- Apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Contact: communityservices@georgebrown.ca, Farhia Abdi (fabdi7@georgebrown.ca, 416-415-5000 ext. 3926).
- Field placement partners may require proof of vaccination.
- International Contact Us page for country-specific recruitment representatives.

For domestic students:
- Apply through Ontario Colleges.

Special requirements:
- Police Vulnerable Sector Check (fees vary by region, takes up to four months).
- Suppression and Destruction of Record or Record Suspension (formerly known as Pardon) at regional police services.

Contacts:
- School of Social & Community Services: communityservices@georgebrown.ca
- Community Worker Program Co-ordinator: Farhia Abdi (fabdi7@georgebrown.ca, 416-415-5000 ext. 3926).

Related programs:
- Social Service Worker (C119)
- Social Service Worker (Accelerated)

Context: The following programs are offered by George Brown College in the area of social services: Social Service Worker (C119), Social Service Worker (Accelerated) (C135), and Child and Youth Care (C133). Interested individuals can book campus tours, info sessions, and sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process on the college website. The applicants are required to provide their first name, last name, email address, and indicate whether they are domestic or international students. They also need to agree to receive email communications from George Brown College.
